ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Read a lot of essays and learned a lot just through writing; really good if you want to write a lot of essays and especially helpful if you schedule meetings with professor riley (she's really kind about that and tries helping) or a writing tutor
Understanding how to discuss readings and relate them to the bigger idea. Appreciate elegant writing and critically analyze how different authors approach topics.
This course developed my writing skills, and I learned to effectively incorporate the stylistic/rhetorical devices from readings into my own essays.

This course was the perfect introduction to college. It taught me to participate in a college seminar, to write and then re-write based on feedback, to read more carefully and always with a pencil (!), and to learn to love to write. I gained speaking, writing and time-management skills that have left me feeling better prepared for other classes at Yale.
A more critical and appreciative style of reading, more purposeful and on task writing
Developed better writing skills; learned to appreciate different forms of essays

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strength: writing and reading (also kinda crazy reading your classmates work and being like DANG they can write) 

professor riley is kind and knowledgeable but also keeps the class somewhat more professional

weakness: our class was a little dry at times, and I feel like the way professor riley handled some discussions concerning race felt kinda off-color in our class? we read some diverse works but they sometimes felt like tokens instead of just generally a diverse syllabus

Strength: All the readings were very interesting and was a great introduction to the English department. A good amount for each week that was reasonable to finish reading and evaluate. 
Weakness: Hard to facilitate a natural and inclusive group conversation over zoom.

Strength: professor, class structure, assignments
Weakness: n/a (I wish the classes were longer so we would have time to discuss all the readings).

One of the strengths of this course is that for each essay, we received feedback on a rough draft from Professor Riley, and then we had another week to apply that feedback and improve it before submitting the final draft. This system of turning in an essay nearly every week and alternating between rough drafts and final drafts, really helped me learn what worked and what didn't in my writing and also in my writing process. Another strength of this course is Professor Riley! She provides great feedback, is very good at facilitating discussion in class and is endlessly helpful!

Strengths: Professor Riley was amazing; she was so kind and caring. I also liked the format of having a first draft, comments, then revised version for each essay. Weaknesses: I felt the essays could have been better paced throughout the semester, as it felt like the last 3/5 essays were a little crammed into the last weeks of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: we were asked at first to unmute ourselves and just talk whenever but eventually everyone muted themselves and we had a lot of awkward silence; spending more time getting to know each other, having a class groupchat, workshopping essays one-on-one might be nice
The requirement to keep your camera on helped with engagement a lot. It was hard to at first to learn to just jump in and speak, but it got more natural at the end.
Professor Riley always found a way to make each class engaging by doing a different writing activity or an interesting discussion.

This course seemed to work well in a virtual setting. It was hard to feel connected to classmates, and zoom made discussion difficult, but we still managed to have great conversations in class. We were asked to keep our mics to make people feel like they could just jump in, but I don't think it helped very much.  Breakout rooms take a lot of time out of class, but it was nice to meet classmates during that time. I wonder if there could be student collaboration outside of class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in a writing credit that has more writing creatively and more interesting readings (that aren't toooo long or rigorous), then this is a lovely course and does expose you to a lot of different works/ideas. If you are interested in creative writing, it might be good to also look at other courses (engl 123, etc.)

Yes, if you prefer personal essays compared to essays that analyze a reading, you'll much prefer this class. Also, if you like to read more modern readings and authors I would suggest this class over the other introductory english courses.
yes
Yes, especially with Professor Riley! This course helped improve my writing so much and taught me a lot about the revision process.
YES! I loved this course so much. It was a great introduction to a Yale education, the reading material is amazing and your writing and reading skills will improve more than you think possible.
Great Writing fulfillment, but even if that werent so, still a great course if you have any interest at all in reading or writing non fiction
Yes, absolutely.
